content_scrubbed:
I actually believe this to be true. "Level headed" types love to scoff at the arts majors, but while they are snorting into their keyboards, programming, engineering, medicine, systems analysis and maintenance, finance, IT, manufacturing, media planning, gambling, and basically anything that involves metrics or software, including managing a fucking baseball team, is rapidly losing competitiveness to bots.

I am a commercial editor, I make trailers for videogames, and I've had this conversation many times. "When will producers start outsourcing my work to India, and then to robots".  So far, in most cases, they can't.  My craft involves understanding and predicting human response to images, cultural backstory, emotion, sound, and music.  I manage human expectations, and thwart them, then satisfy them. I drop subconscious cultural references that are felt, but not overtly duplicated. My job is to play human beings like a pipe organ, where some of the levers diddle primal instincts, and some make a joke about something 2 days old from Reddit. There is no outsourcing that cultural dexterity and there certainly is no software plug-in that can get that right. 

Bots can and will make "cool" art. They will make things that are beautiful. They won't make things that are subversively meaningful. They won't do investigative journalism. They won't sing from the heart. They won't illustrate children[.] books anytime soon, compose soundtracks, or direct films. They will take STEM jobs before they take songwriters' jobs.
